description:
As I was trying to use the "style" feature as described in the docs  (http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/visualizing/plots.html#types-of-projections), I encountered some errors because of a mistake in the docs.

I realized that (1) the docs are wrong in that they reference "style" instead of "proj_style" associated with ProjectionPlot; (2) there are no docstrings in ProjectionPlot for the use of this attribute; and (3) the QuadTree data object (which is what the ProjectionPlot generates for the projection) has the attribute labeled as "style", whereas ProjectionPlot has it labeled as "proj_style".

I figure this change makes the code more internally consistent, adds docstrings, and brings the code in line with our published documentation.  I'm guessing that not many people will notice this API breakage since our public-facing docs were directing them to use the "style" keyword in the first place, but I'm open to hearing from the other devs on this.  What do you peeps think?

UPDATE1: Realized there was also a bug when using the 'mip' style which yielded the wrong field units off by a factor of `length`.  A demonstration of this is to take a `ProjectionPlot(ds,'x','density','mip')` and see the projected units as `g/cm**2` instead of `g/cm**3`.  Corrected this.  Also reinstated `proj_style` keyword in ProjectionPlot but deprecated it in the docstrings. 

UPDATE2: Changed "style" to "method" throughout ProjectionPlot and QuadTree. Updated docs too.

UPDATE3: Fixed a problem with nosetest failing.  Needed to switch the cython code where the QuadTree object is defined to switch "style" keyword to "method" keyword.  This is fixed, however, it now requires one to rebuild yt (i.e. `python setup.py develop`) to make the appropriate c code.  Ugh.

UPDATE4: Made "style" a deprecated but allowed keyword for the QuadTree object.  Updated the docs.  Added a test to PlotWindow tests for all projection methods: 'mip', 'sum', 'integrate'.
title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: Can you leave `proj_style` in the API, but mark it as deprecated?  We can remove it in a version or two.
content.html: Can you leave proj_style in the API, but mark it as deprecated? We can remove it in a version or two.

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: Sure, that makes sense.  That's a good compromise if we are going to switch to `style`.
content.html: Sure, that makes sense. That's a good compromise if we are going to switch to style.

content.raw: When you say "mark as deprecated", you just mean mention in the docstring that it is deprecated?  Or also mention elsewhere in the docs?  or do something else?
content.html: When you say "mark as deprecated", you just mean mention in the docstring that it is deprecated? Or also mention elsewhere in the docs? or do something else?

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: Mention that as of the yt 3.0.2 release, it's deprecated. You'll also need to add some logic to make sure it's assigned to `style` if someone passes it in.
content.html: Mention that as of the yt 3.0.2 release, it's deprecated. You'll also need to add some logic to make sure it's assigned to style if someone passes it in.

content.raw: Yes & no: it looks like the problem was that I didn't switch the QuadTree cython code to incorporate the change from "style" to "method".  Should be fixed now.
content.html: Yes & no: it looks like the problem was that I didn't switch the QuadTree cython code to incorporate the change from "style" to "method". Should be fixed now.

content.html: I mean to say, don't you need to preserve this keyword but mark it as deprecated in the docstrings, just like proj_style for ProjectionPlot?

content.html: Oh, you're absolutely right. I'll fix that. Sorry--I didn't anticipate making such a substantial change to everything. I just wanted to bring the code in-line with the docs and self-consistent.

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: I had to update the cython code to accept the "method" keyword as well as the "style" keyword or else trying to initialize the QuadTree object in python would fail.  This is what caused the test failure after UPDATE2.
content.html: I had to update the cython code to accept the "method" keyword as well as the "style" keyword or else trying to initialize the QuadTree object in python would fail. This is what caused the test failure after UPDATE2.

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: What I was getting at was really that the Cython QuadTree isn't really a "public" API, and only gets called inside the Python code.  So instead of changing it, you could just change the Python code that calls it.  It's not a big deal.
content.html: What I was getting at was really that the Cython QuadTree isn't really a "public" API, and only gets called inside the Python code. So instead of changing it, you could just change the Python code that calls it. It's not a big deal.

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: I removed the extra deprecation check from the QuadTree cython code, so there is no check for "style" as a keyword (since all calls to the QuadTree code switch `style` to `method`).  I thought it would be better to retain the same keyword in the cython code that is called from the python code (i.e. `method`) instead of having `method` in the python code and `style` in the cython code.
content.html: I removed the extra deprecation check from the QuadTree cython code, so there is no check for "style" as a keyword (since all calls to the QuadTree code switch style to method). I thought it would be better to retain the same keyword in the cython code that is called from the python code (i.e. method) instead of having method in the python code and style in the cython code.

content.raw:
Nope, although I am still unclear on why the change to the instantiation of
QuadTree, whose API in Cython hasn't changed, isn't breaking the tests.

pullrequest.title: [APICHANGE] [BUGFIX] Changing ProjectionPlot's "proj_style" attribute to be "style" attribute

content.raw: The API in Cython has changed from `style` to `method` just like the API in Python has changed from `style` to `method`.  The code I removed from cython earlier was just the deprecated `style` keyword, since it should only be called from within python, and all the calls in python are for `method`.
content.html: The API in Cython has changed from style to method just like the API in Python has changed from style to method. The code I removed from cython earlier was just the deprecated style keyword, since it should only be called from within python, and all the calls in python are for method.
